Author: Anon84
Content:
I'm not sure I would consider RMS a "marketing team"... he would be an evangelist at best. And as far as a mission statement he's probably thinking of something people can understand and relate to. Say something like "a PC in every desk" and not a spiel about how you should prefer inferior software just because it gives you the option of looking at/modifying the code... when 90% of the users would never do that.

An analogy I've heard used several times. Proprietary software is like a tea set. There are differences in quality and features and it's limited in its use (you probably don't want to use your tea set to cook rice). FLOSS is like a piece of clay... sure, you can use it to build a better tea set, and it can even come already shaped like one that you just have to cook, but most of the times you're buying a tea set because you just want to drink tea.

heh... just $.02 on it.

Author: jacobbijani

Author: alex_c
Title: Reminder: Monday is D-Day for Facebook apps
Content:
Facebook is going to gradually start rolling in the new profile on Monday. If you have Facebook apps, or if you just want to get an early peek at the redesigned profile, visit:

http://www.new.facebook.com/

(you might have to go there after logging in to Facebook through the normal URL).

More details of the changes (for app developers) here:

http://developers.facebook.com/news.php?blog=1&story=130

Title: The web is a fuzz test: patch your browser and your web server

Author: patrickg-zill
Content:
You don't need to read the Economist. All you have to do is look at the numbers from DOE themselves, and make up your own mind.

Personally I believe we are nowhere near peak oil, due to Bakken, the unexplored resources off USA coastal shorelines, ANWR drilling that should be undertaken, etc.

Plus for natural gas we have the undersea hydrates that we haven't quite figured out how to mine cheaply (yet).

Author: gecko
Content: In college, there may be some, but they're few and far between--largely because they, like you, are holed up in their dorms all day playing WoW.  Once you graduate, and you both start having more normal lives, it gets much easier. Here in NYC, I've not had any trouble finding geek-compatible girls, and have been in several overall very pleasant relationships over the past couple of years.  You just have to be willing to look.

Author: baha_man
Content:
'There is no free software marketing team, no advertising budget, no "mission statement". Free software and GNU/Linux are simply there.'

The author is using the term 'GNU/Linux' but appears not to have heard of Richard Stallman.

Author: mlinsey
Content: You can reap other benefits from scarcity besides charging for the scarce product.  To take an example from your list, I think "scarcity" helped Facebook a lot in the early days when you had to have a valid email address from one of a small list of schools in order to have an account.

Author: davidw
Content: "Free" stuff still falls under the purview of economics because there is some scarcity lurking somewhere, as you correctly point out.  It's just funny to read "economics of scarcity" if you are familiar with one of the traditional definitions of economics.
